title: Continually Learned Pavlovian Signalling Without Forgetting for Human-in-the-Loop Robotic Control. (arXiv:2305.14365v1 [cs.LG])
abstract: Artificial limbs are sophisticated devices to assist people with tasks of daily living. Despite advanced robotic prostheses demonstrating similar motion capabilities to biological limbs, users report them difficult and non-intuitive to use. Providing more effective feedback from the device to the user has therefore become a topic of increased interest. In particular, prediction learning methods from the field of reinforcement learning -- specifically, an approach termed Pavlovian signalling -- have been proposed as one approach for better modulating feedback in prostheses since they can adapt during continuous use. One challenge identified in these learning methods is that they can forget previously learned predictions when a user begins to successfully act upon delivered feedback. translated_title: 面向人机交互机器人控制的连续学习巴甫洛夫信号传递方法
translated_abstract: 人工肢体是一种辅助人们日常生活任务的复杂设备。尽管先进的机械假肢展示了类似于生物肢体的运动能力，但用户报告它们难以使用并且不直观。因此，提供更有效的来自设备到用户的反馈已经成为越来越受关注的话题。具体来说，强化学习领域的预测学习方法——具体地说，一种名为巴甫洛夫信号传递的方法，已被提出作为改进假肢反馈调节的一种方法，因为它们可以在连续使用过程中进行自适应。其中一个挑战是，这些学习方法会在用户开始成功地行动所提供的反馈时忘记先前学习的预测。本研究直接解决了这个问题，并就算法选择（如on-policy和off-policy方法以及表示选择）对巴甫洛夫信号传递的影响提供了新证据。
tldr: 本文研究了面向机器人控制的巴甫洛夫信号传递方法如何进行连续学习而不会忘记之前的预测结果，研究发现算法选择（如on-policy和off-policy方法以及表示选择）会影响传递的效果。
en_tdlr: This paper explores how the Pavlovian signalling approach can be used for robotic control and adapt to continuous learning without forgetting previous predictions, and shows that algorithmic choices (such as on-/off-policy and representation) have an impact on the effectiveness of this approach.
